What is the average level of import duties for components needed for a solar project (panels and inverts)?

sectionCopy.name: Clean energy policy
sectionCopy.value: Latin America's largest economy is restrained by tepid growth as it limps back from a deep recession in 2015-16. Brazil's GDP expanded just 1.1% in 2018, and growth has remained near 1% for the past two and a half years. Sluggish growth is expected to persist through the end of 2019, with annual GDP growth forecast cut from 2.4% in March to 0.8% in September. Unemployment remains high, productivity lags and public debt has risen. Inflation has grown slower than anticipated and is expected to end 2019 at 3.6% vs. a target of 4.25%.

sectionCopy.name: Clean energy investment
sectionCopy.value: The Dominican Republic's clean energy sector attracted $1.4 billion of investment over 2010-2018. Wind energy captured the bulk of it, $746 million, followed by solar with $298 million. Over half of the investment was recorded on the past two years. Most renewable energy projects are financed by project developers and multilateral investment banks. Commercial banks have limited participation in the market.

sectionCopy.name: Power prices and LCOEs
sectionCopy.value: The Dominican Republic's residential power prices averaged $133.80/MWh in 2018 compared to $152.49/MWh in 2015.  Commercial prices fell over this period from $217/MWh in 2015 to $176.60/MWh in 2018. Average industrial prices decreased from $210.69/MWh in 2015 to $145.80/MWh in 2018. In contrast, wholesale prices jumped from $96/MWh in 2015 to $141/MWh in 2018, representing an increase of 46% over the period. The culprit was retail rate subsidies, which are estimated to have cost $479 million in 2018 alone. With the commissioning of the Punta Catalina thermal power plant in 2019, the government foresees a reduction in electricity prices and subsidies.

sectionCopy.name: Power market
sectionCopy.value: The Dominican Republic had 3.6GW of installed capacity in 2018. Oil and diesel are the main sources of electricity, accounting for 1.6GW, or approximately 50% of total capacity. Small hydro, wind, solar and biomass together account for 13% of the total. Although generation is open to private players, it remains dominated by state-owned entities. The distribution segment is divided into three public companies: Edeeste, Edenorte and Edesur. All state-owned companies are managed by the Corporación Dominicana de Empresas Eléctricas Estatales (CDEEE).

sectionCopy.name: Doing business
sectionCopy.value:
In 2018, the Dominican Republic's electrification rate was 96%. Peak power demand jumped 26%, from 1,810MW in 2010 to 2,280MW in 2018, while generation grew 21% over the same period. 
On January 7, 2019, the Dominican Republic's National Energy Commission (CNE) published a resolution on clean energy auctions. According to this document, national and international companies are allowed to participate, but additional details are not available. On May 27, 2019, CNE authorized 12 provisional concessions for electricity generation, of which two are wind projects and eight are photovoltaic projects corresponding to 874MW in total. The government announced on May 2019 that will invest $900 million in clean energy projects.

sectionCopy.name: Barriers
sectionCopy.value:
Formal barriers to development of renewables in Dominican Republic are low. An incentive regime for the development of clean energy has been in place since May 2007, consistent with the national energy plan (the Plan Energ'tico Nacional, or PEN). It includes an investment tax credit, external financing, tax reductions, and exemptions from taxes on the transfer of industrialized goods and services and from import duties. Renewable energy generators have dispatch priority and open access to transmission and distribution.
Beyond that, the financial instability of the Corporación Dominicana de Empresas Eléctricas Estatales (CDEEE) and the subsidization of retail electricity prices jeopardizes project developers seeking financing and the low rates for electricity prices difficult the entrance of new energy technologies.
